Kevin,

Let me add to Charles comments a bit...although Charles does a good=
 
job giving some background, I believe there are some things Charles 
didn=
't mention you should be aware of.

First, see the question, "How are netwo=
rks with arbitrary topologies 
activated?" in the NEAT FAQ located at:

htt=
p://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html

That question gives some ba=
ckground on your own question.

The short answer is that every node is acti=
vated on every timestep 
from ALL incoming connections.  Any node that has =
not yet received 
input it assumed to be outputting a zero.  In other words=
, time 
delay does not enter into it at all (I have never actually used the=
 
time-delay code).  Also, activation does not travel all the way from 
inp=
uts to outputs in a single timestep unless there is a direct 
connection fr=
om inputs to outputs.  But activation traveling over 
intervening nodes wil=
l take extra time to get there.

So what happens is that a node that connec=
ts to itself receives the 
activation that itself output on the *previous* =
timestep.  Networks 
are activated over a series of timesteps.

It is impor=
tant to note that you should *not* be relaxing a network 
during a control =
task like food gathering.  Charles mentions 
relaxation but that is only ap=
propriate for classification tasks 
where the network is trying to decide o=
n a final answer.  See the 
question, "How do I ensure that a network stabi=
lizes before taking 
its output(s) for a classification problem?" in the NE=
AT FAQ for 
more info on this.

In a continual control task like food gathe=
ring (or most tasks NEAT 
is used for) there is always new input coming in =
and new output 
coming out, so the network will never relax, since there is=
 
no "final" answer.  The only question that comes up is how many 
times (s=
teps) to activate the network per world tick.  Almost any 
experiment I've =
heard of activates once per tick, but it is possible 
to imagine activating=
 >1 time per tick, which is equivalent to 
speeding up the rate of thought.=
   However, note that more 
activations also means more CPU time per world =
tick.

I hope this help; feel free to ask any other questions.

ken




---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, Charles Tarun <ctarun@g...> wrote:
> Hello Maitri=
karuna,
> I would like to offer any help I can, and I'm sure others will 
a=
lso help,
> 
> I also don't have any training on NN either, but I've been r=
ead a 
lot about 
> them. Each implementation of NEAT handles the firing of=
 the node 
in their 
> own way, as NEAT doesn't define it exactly. My metho=
d of choice is 
one of 
> the SharpNEAT ones, "FastConcurrentNetwork". This=
 network 
simulates each 
> neuron activating concurrently.
> 
> 1) Assign =
the values to all input nodes
> 2) Activate the network 
> 3) Relax the net=
work
> 4) Read the outputs
> 
> Activate network is pass a parameter of how=
 many times to run for, 
this is 
> basically how many steps to run for. Ea=
ch step uses the signal 
strength from 
> the previous.
> 
> The Relax netw=
ork function is very much like the Activate 
function, but also 
> take in =
a maxAllowedSignalDelta. It runs until the signal change 
for each 
> node =
is <maxAllowedSignalDelta or the maxSteps count is reached. 
> 
> |-------
=
> v |
> NODE1-->NODE2-->NODE3
> 
> They way I see this working with your di=
agram is(assuming the 
links had 
> enough weight to cause the next to fire=
):
> 
> Step 1:
> Node1(input) is firing.
> node2 get enough signal to fire=
 at this time stamp
> node3 only getting signal from the previous step when=
 node2 wasn't 
firing 
> does not have enough signal to fire.
> 
> Step2:
>=
 Node1(input) is firing.
> node2 gets enough signal to fire from node1's la=
st step, but is 
not getting 
> signal from node3.
> node3 gets enough sign=
al to fire from node2's last step and fires
> 
> step3:
> Node1(input) is f=
iring(As always, input nodes don't change)
> node2 is getting signal from n=
ode1 and node3 now
> node3 is getting signal from node2 last time step, the=
 recurrent 
connection 
> hasn't effected the signal from 2 to 3 yet.
> 
> =
Under such a system it is possible to get oscillation in the 
signals, that=
's 
> why there is a maxSteps on the relax function. The creator of 
SharpN=
EAT is 
> part of this list as well(Colin D. Green). I hope this will be 
h=
elpful.
> 
> Chuck Tarun
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On 8/24/05, maitrikaruna <kevin@t...=
> wrote:
> > 
> > Hello all,
> > 
> > I stumbled on NEAT just a short week =
ago and have found it very

menting NEAT in
> > PowerBASIC and I'm nearly done. I am doing a rather sim=
ple
> > simulation.
> > 
> > I basically set up a "room" and drop an agent =
in the middle.
> > The
> > agent needs to eat=85so I place a large circle r=
epresenting
food in
> > the
> > room. The agent has so many steps to find t=
he food or it
> > disappears. The food is then moved to a new location and =
the 
agent
> > can try again. The agent is tested against four different fo=
od
> > locations. The agent has 8 sensors that allow it to "see" in
> > tho=
se 8
> > directions.
> > 
> > Right now with only 50 parents and 10 generat=
ions it is able to 
find
> > all the 4 different food bins after about9 or =
10 gens...which is
> > pretty good.. Especially since I discovered that I h=
ave a neuron
> > firing issue in my code..
> > 
> > Anyway..I am completely=
 new to NN's...i have no training on them 
at
> > all, although I do know G=
A's fairly well (I am CEO of 
bioinformatics
> > firm that uses GA's to ana=
lyze genetics data).
> > 
> > I have a question I hope you can help with. t=
he way I setup the
> > networks allows for recurrent connections to occur. =
So suppose 
you
> > have a simple netowrk where input node 1 connects to hi=
dden node 
2,
> > which connects to hidden node 3, which connects to back t=
o node 
2.
> > How is firing to proceed in such a scenario? Node 2 can't fi=
re
> > until it has all its inputs, yet one of its outputs(the one to 
node=

> > 3) affects what its input will be. Thanks for your help...
> > |------=
-
> > v |
> > NODE1-->NODE2-->NODE3
> > 
> > And what if a node links back =
to itself? Then how is the firing
> > sequence to work? I saw a time delay =
in teh C code and I am
> > guessing this is involved, but I'm not quite sur=
e how...
> > 
> > When I get this working, I would like to tackle the tic-t=
ac-toe
> > problem you guys are working on.
> > 
> > i really appreciate al=
l your posts...very enlightening...
